subject: RE: [junit] How to test a bussiness method returns a enumeration
msgSnippet: ... This doesn t test whether or not the Enumerations are iterating over the same collection... thus, your next point. ... However, if you don t have a
messageBody:
> You can test that the Collection contains elements or
> that the Enumeration is
> not empty.
>
> assert(enumeration.hasMoreElements());
> assert(!collection.isEmpty()); //or if you expect it to be empty
> assert(collection.isEmpty());

This doesn't test whether or not the Enumerations are iterating over the
same collection... thus, your next point.

> You can test the value of each element of the Collection
> or Enumeration.
>
> //loop over enumeration
> SomeClass sc = (SomeClass) enumeration.nextElement();
> assertEquals(some_value, sc.getSomeValue());

However, if you don't have a Comparator for these objects, the equals()
method will test that they are the same object in memory, which will
invariably cause the test to fail. So, if these objects are your own
objects, you can override the equals() method on the object. If they are
not your own you have to write a Comparator for them (or something
equivalent).

-Jason
